title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: Our route to church was a lane calledWindmill Lane, which had many stables in it; thislane is bisected by a cross street called WindmillStreet, at the eastern end whereof there is a junctionof several streets, of which the narrowest and dingiestis the Potterrow. At the top of the Potterrow is alane at the back of the College, which led to anotherlane called the Horse Wynd, which descended to theCowgate. Right across the Cowgate is the Fishmarket Close, the top of which debouched on theHigh Street, but near the top of the close was a stairleading to the Parliament Close or Square immediately at the end of the High Church or St Giles'.

title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: When we thought we had trespassed long enoughon the hospitality of our Congregationalist friends,in November 1843 we resumed possession of our oldmeeting-house in Brighton Street, the residuary congregation having been transferred to West St Giles'. We continued there till the church was sold over ourheads, and we found refuge in Dr Ritchie's church inthe Potterrow in 1846, and were there till our newchurch in Forrest Road was opened in June 1848.

title: The complete works of Robert Burns :

snippet: Bums had at length, early in December 1787 (after having in vain waited for a final settlement with Mr. Creech,) resolved on leaving Edinburgh, when an accident occurred which had the effect of detaining him for at least three months longer. A Miss Nimmo, residing in Allison Square, Potterrow, of whom the poet was an occasional visitor, (in respect she was the intimate friend of his correspondent Miss Chalmers), had a small tea-party in her house about the beginning of December,  where he was a principal guest. Another ' ' principal guest" on that occasion was Mrs. M'Lehose, a familiar acquaintance  of Miss Nimmo, who after reading Bums's poems and hearing him so greatly spoken of, had earnestly pressed her friend to make them acquainted.

snippet: It struck me they were disguised, for the guard were for the most part gray- headed, while both my captors were young, the elder not yet middle-aged. They seemed greatly excited, but did not threaten me in any way, and in a very few seconds we reached the Potterrow, and I was lugged headlong up a steep stair and so into a room ; and I deemed it wisest just then to make no resistance, though I vowed to give them some trouble when I got my arms free. title: New North Church, Edinburgh
author: Livingston, Josiah.
snippet: But to return to the New North itself. While thecongregation was worshipping in the Potterrow, amidconsiderable discouragement from the state of MrBrown's health, every exertion was being used tohave a new church built, and a site having beenobtained on what was then the grounds of theCity Poorhouse, our present church was built onwhat was considered a commanding position, at a costof upwards of £7000, and to this we migrated inJune 1848. The architect was Mr Hamilton, whogave at first a very handsome plan, to cost £7000.

title: To arms! :
author: Balfour, Andrew
snippet: It became my custom in the evenings to spend an hour in the Potterrow, and listen to Kenneth's tales, while his brothers glowered at us, and now and then delivered themselves of some small phrase which they had picked up. I found that Kenneth Campbell, who was of about my own age, had a touch of the poet's nature in him, and he was great upon his home by Inverary, and on the beauties of wild Loch Awe, while he could sing a song of the Gaelic very plaintively,  so as to bring tears into the eyes of Donald Dhu and Malcolm More.
